title: Re: re: can you see if this site loads up on your computer?
content:
You'll need to log in with 'quost' and there will be somewhere where you can put in the IP addresses of your nameservers - you'll need two before the domain will become active. Some places will provide you with nameservers so you don't have to run your own, but for $18 I doubt they would. The alternative is to get your web host to run these, they'll usually throw that in for free as part of your web hosting package.

Telstra probably isn't the cheapest web host out there, but assuming you have a proper web hosting package (not someone's home Internet connection) then you'll be able to log in to their web page and set up your domain from there (they'll also give you the nameserver IPs to put into your Quost account.)

title: Re: re: can you see if this site loads up on your computer?
content:
You've now got nameservers looking after the domain, but you still have to tell those nameservers where your website is hosted. At the moment the name "www" isn't pointing to an IP address, so when you visit "www.thecrew.org.au" your web browser doesn't know which server to connect to (it asks the nameservers you've configured, but at the moment the nameservers are replying with "I don't know" so the web browser gives up.)

You'll need to tell your nameservers that the hostname "www" should point to the IP address of your web host - and you'll need to ask your web host what their server's IP address is for this (usually they'll tell you in their hosting FAQ.)

You'll need to tell your nameservers that the hostname "www" should point to the IP address of your web host - and you'll need to ask your web host what their server's IP address is for this (usually they'll tell you in their hosting FAQ.) [hr][/quote]

title: Re: re: can you see if this site loads up on your computer?
content: If you're running Windows, open a command prompt and type "ping www.thecrew.org.au" - I get an error "unknown host www.thecrew.org.au" which means I won't be able to see the web site.  You *should* get the same error, and then you can just play around with the DNS until you fix the ping error.

title: Re: re: can you see if this site loads up on your computer?
content: The problem is that the DNS servers that thecrew.org.au is pointed at are not returning the correct IP address to computers on the public internet. When I ping the IP address that thecrew.org.au is shown to resolve to below (61.9.143.4), it works fine.[url=http://toxicsheep.com]toxicsheep.com[/url] | [url=http://commanderkeen.org]coming up next...[/url]

title: Re: re: can you see if this site loads up on your computer?
content:
so as you can see when i pinged www.thecrew.org.au from a st.l computer i don't get an error

It looks like you must have some internal server performing this job, which is why it seems to work fine for you, but nowhere else. Ask your network person why it works inside your network but not outside, and they'll know why.

title: Re: re: can you see if this site loads up on your computer?
content:
But what happens if they're running Linux on their servers? [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-cheeky.gif[/img] Your dad would get fired for helping [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img]

Rorie, Grafix was right, I have no idea why it's not working. The domain lists the nameservers as Telstra's, so you could try asking Telstra how to set up domain names that were registered through them. I suspect when you (or "Stephen Oakes") registered the domain, you were given a username and password to log in to Telstra's domain management site. Log in here, and that's where you'll be able to add hosts. You'll need to add a host called "www" and give it the IP address of your webserver (this is probably the same IP that comes up when you ran that 'ping' thing at St. Laurence.) If you still can't get it to work, ask Stephen who he contacted to register the domain, and ring those people up and ask them how to do it.

I'm still stumped as to why it does work within St. Laurence, though.
